{{Other people}} {{pp-vandalism|expiry=01:00, 9 February 2019|small=yes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Wendy Williams | image = Wendy Williams.png | caption = Williams in November 2011 | birth_name = Wendy Joan Williams | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1964|7|18}} | birth_place = [[Ocean Township, Monmouth County, New Jersey]], U.S. | residence = | occupation = {{flatlist| * Television host * author * actress * producer * fashion designer * former radio personality }} | known_for = ''[[The Wendy Williams Show]]'', ''The Wendy Williams Experience'' | years_active = 1983–present | alma_mater = [[Northeastern University]] | spouse = {{marriage|Kevin Hunter|1997}} | children = 1 | net worth = US$60 million | website = [http://www.wendyshow.com www.wendyshow.com] }} '''Wendy Joan Williams-Hunter''' (born '''Wendy Joan Williams'''; July 18, 1964)<ref name="Wendy Williams.Biography"/> is an American television host, actress, author, fashion designer, and former radio personality. She has hosted the [[broadcast syndication|nationally syndicated]] television talk show ''[[The Wendy Williams Show]]'' since 2008.
Prior to television, Williams was a radio DJ and host and quickly became known in New York as a "[[shock jock]]ette". She gained notoriety for her on-air spats with celebrities and was the subject of the 2006 [[VH1]] reality TV series ''[[The Wendy Williams Experience]]'' which broadcast events surrounding her radio show. She was inducted into the [[National Radio Hall of Fame]] in 2009.
She has written a [[The New York Times Best Seller list|''New York Times'' best-selling]] autobiography and six other books, and has created various product lines including a fashion line, a jewelry collection and a wig line. On her 50th birthday, the council of [[Asbury Park#Notable people|Asbury Park]] renamed the street on which she grew up to Wendy Williams Way.
==Early life== Williams was born on July 18, 1964, in [[Ocean Township, Monmouth County, New Jersey]], a suburb of [[Asbury Park, New Jersey|Asbury Park]].<ref name="Wendy Williams.Biography">{{cite web |title=Wendy Williams Biography| url=http://www.biography.com/people/wendy-williams-524056|accessdate=May 14, 2013| journal=biography.com}}</ref> She is the second of three children born to parents Thomas and Shirley Williams.<ref name="Wendy Williams.Biography"/> She grew up in the Wayside section of Ocean Township.<ref name=NYmagProfile>[http://nymag.com/nymetro/news/people/features/14790/index1.html "How New York's Shock Jockette Got Supersized"], ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'', October 16, 2005, Accessed September 18, 2006</ref> Williams graduated from [[Ocean Township High School]]<ref name=NJMonthly>Neglia, Ashley V. [http://njmonthly.com/articles/lifestyle/njmyway/mixing-media.html "Mixing Media"], ''[[New Jersey Monthly]]'', June 9, 2008, Accessed July 22, 2008</ref> and, from 1982 to 1986, she attended [[Northeastern University (Boston, Massachusetts)|Northeastern University]] in [[Boston, Massachusetts]], where she graduated<ref name="vibe2003">{{cite book |title=Drama Queen|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2yYEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA160|accessdate=March 25, 2013|author= Lola Ogunnaike|date= October 3, 2003|publisher=Vibe Media Group|pages=160–}}</ref> with a B.A. in communications and was a DJ for the college radio station [[WRBB]].
==Career== ===Radio=== Williams began her career working for [[WVIS]] in the [[United States Virgin Islands]].<ref name="vibe2003"/> Less than a year later, she obtained an afternoon position at [[Washington, D.C.]]-based station [[WOL (AM)|WOL]]. Williams commuted between DC and [[Queens, New York]], to work an overnight weekend shift at [[WQHT]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/how-wendy-williams-got-her-start-2013-6|title=Every College Grad Should Hear Wendy Williams' Story About Struggling To Make It Big|accessdate=June 27, 2017}}</ref>
In 1989, Williams began at [[urban contemporary]] WRKS (now [[WEPN-FM]]) in New York City as a substitute disc jockey. WRKS hired her full-time for its morning show. A year later, Williams moved to an afternoon drive-time shift, eventually winning the ''[[Billboard magazine|Billboard]]'' Award for "Best On-Air Radio Personality" in 1993.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} In December 1994, [[Emmis Broadcasting]] purchased WRKS and switched Williams to the company's other New York property, hip-hop formatted [[WQHT]] ("Hot 97"), as WRKS was reformatted into an [[urban adult contemporary]] outlet. She was fired from Hot 97 in 1998.<ref name=NYmagProfile/>
Williams was hired by a Philadelphia urban station, [[WUSL]] ("Power 99FM"). Her husband, Kevin Hunter, became her agent.<ref name=NYmagProfile/> She was very open about her personal life on air, discussing her miscarriages, breast enhancement surgery<ref name=NYmagProfile/> and former drug addiction.<ref name="vibe2003"/> She helped the station move from 14th place in the ratings to 2nd.<ref name=NYmagProfile/>
Williams has stated that [[Bill Cosby]] attempted to get her fired in 1991 and 1992. She also believes that [[Bill Cosby sexual assault allegations|Cosby is guilty of sexual assault]].<ref name="EURweb 2017">{{cite web | title=Wendy Williams Reveals Bill Cosby Tried to Get Her Fired... TWICE | website=EURweb | date=July 29, 2017 | url=https://www.eurweb.com/2017/07/wendy-williams-reveals-bill-cosby-tried-to-get-her-fired-twice/ | access-date=July 30, 2017}}</ref>
In 2001, Williams returned to the New York airwaves when WBLS hired her full-time for a syndicated 2–6 p.m. time slot. Williams' friend, MC Spice of Boston, offered his voiceover services to the show, often adding short rap verses tailored specifically for Williams' show. ''The New York Times'' stated that her "show works best when its elements – confessional paired with snarkiness – are conflated," and cited a 2003 interview with [[Whitney Houston]] as an example.<ref name="NYT2008">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/13/arts/television/13drak.html?_r=0|title=TELEVISION; A Radio Shock Jock Who's Ready for TV|last=Drake|first=Monica|date=July 13, 2008|work=The New York Times|page=17|accessdate=April 15, 2013}}</ref> During the highly publicized interview<ref name="FOX">{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,389263,00.html|title=Omarosa: Wendy Williams a 'Fake and a Phony' |work=[[Fox News Channel]]|accessdate=April 15, 2013|date=July 23, 2008}}</ref> that "went haywire" and included "a lot of bleeped language", Williams "asked [Houston], insistently, about her drug and spending habits".<ref name="Stanley2008">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/22/arts/television/22stan.html|title=Talk Show Is Less Talk, More Alpha-Female Action |author=Alessandra Stanley |date=July 22, 2008 |work=The New York Times|accessdate=April 15, 2013}}</ref>
By 2008, she was syndicated in [[Redondo Beach, California]]; [[Shreveport, Louisiana]]; [[Wilmington, Delaware]]; [[Toledo, Ohio]]; [[Columbia, South Carolina]]; [[Emporia, Virginia]]; [[Lake Charles, Louisiana]]; [[Tyler, Texas]]; and [[Alexandria, Louisiana]], among other markets.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}}
Williams left her radio show in 2009 to focus on her television program and spend more time with her family. She was inducted into the [[National Radio Hall of Fame]].<ref name="Hall of fame">{{cite web|title=National Radio Hall of Fame: Wendy Williams, Talkshow Host|url=http://www.radiohof.org/talkshowhost/wendywilliams.html|access-date=December 25, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091218105840/http://www.radiohof.org/talkshowhost/wendywilliams.html|archive-date=December 18, 2009|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===''The Wendy Williams Show''=== [[File:Wendy-williams1.jpg|thumb|[[All Mobile Video|AMV]] [[53rd Street (Manhattan)|53rd Street]] Studio where the show was produced from Season 1–3]]
In 2008, [[Debmar-Mercury]] offered Williams a six-week television trial of her own talk show. On July 14, 2008, Williams debuted her daytime talk show, ''[[The Wendy Williams Show]]'', in four cities during the summer of 2008. During the tryout, ''[[The New York Times]]'' snarkily remarked that the show created a "breakthrough in daytime" by introducing the genre of the "backtalk show.".<ref>{{cite news |last=Stanley |first=Alessandra |date=July 22, 2008 |title=Talk Show Is Less Talk, More Alpha-Female Action |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/22/arts/television/22stan.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=September 24, 2016}}</ref>
After a successful run, [[Fox Television Stations|Fox]] signed a deal with Debmar-Mercury to broadcast the show nationally on their stations beginning in July 2009. In addition, [[BET]] picked up cable rights to broadcast the show at night. In 2010, BET started airing the show internationally in 54 countries through [[BET International]].<ref> *{{Cite news |last=Littleton |first=Cynthia |url=https://variety.com/2009/scene/markets-festivals/wendy-williams-set-for-july-1117998404/ |title='Wendy Williams' set for July: Talk show goes national this summer |work=Variety |date=January 12, 2009}} *{{cite book |author=Kathleen Fearn-Banks, Anne Burford-Johnson |date=2014 |title=Historical Dictionary of African American Television |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wxa7BAAAQBAJ&pg=PA508 |page=508 |isbn= 0810879174}} *{{cite news |last=Ross |first=Kevin |date=June 1, 2010 |title=BET Networks Acquires Debmar-Mercury’s ‘THE WENDY WILLIAMS SHOW’ for Season Two Domestically; Secures International Channels Rights |url=http://www.radiofacts.com/bet-networks-acquires-debmar-mercurys-the-wendy-williams-show-for-season-two-domestically-secures-international-channels-rights/ |newspaper=Radiofacts |access-date=September 24, 2016}}</ref>
Williams has received multiple nominations at the [[Daytime Emmy Awards]] for Outstanding Entertainment Talk Show Host and the show itself was for Outstanding Talk Show/Entertainment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wendyshow.com/2015/04/01/wendy-williams-nominated-for-a-daytime-emmy-award/#.VXdlzEI-ChI |title=Wendy Williams Nominated for a Daytime Emmy Award! | The Wendy Williams Show |website=Wendyshow.com |date=April 1, 2015 |accessdate=January 5, 2016}}</ref> The show attracts 2.4 million daily viewers on average, with Williams trading off daily with [[Ellen DeGeneres]] as the number one female host on [[daytime television]].<ref name="Bloomberg">{{cite news |last=Rovzar |first=Chris |date=March 4, 2015 |title=How Wendy Williams Became Daytime Talk’s Unlikely Survivor |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-03-04/how-wendy-williams-became-daytime-talk-s-unlikely-survivor |newspaper=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]] |access-date=September 23, 2016 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160731073542/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-03-04/how-wendy-williams-became-daytime-talk-s-unlikely-survivor |archivedate=July 31, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
“The Wendy Williams Show” has been renewed through the 2019-20 television season on the Fox Television Stations.The renewal will keep “Wendy” on air through its 11th season. During the November 2015 sweeps period, the talk show finished either No. 1 or 2 in the key demo of women 25-54 in 55% of the U.S. and 20 of the top-25 markets.<ref>{{cite web|author=Laura Prudom |url=https://variety.com/2016/tv/news/wendy-williams-show-renewed-2020-1201682884/ |title=Wendy Williams Show Renewed Through Season 11 |publisher=Variety |date=January 19, 2016 |accessdate=October 18, 2016}}</ref>
Williams had not missed a show until February 2018, when she took one week off; however, on February 21, 2018, Williams announced that her show would be on three weeks' hiatus due to her complications with [[Graves' disease]] and [[hyperthyroidism]].<ref>{{Citation|last=Wendy Williams|title=A Message from Wendy|date=2018-02-21|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qvZybtmE5RY|accessdate=2018-02-21}}</ref>
===Other television appearances=== Williams has made appearances in the television series ''[[Martin (TV series)|Martin]]'' (1992) and in the soap opera ''[[One Life to Live]]'' (2011).
Williams filled in for [[Jodi Applegate]] on [[WNYW]]'s morning television show, ''[[Good Day New York]]'' (2007), and hosted a game show for [[Game Show Network|GSN]] called ''[[Love Triangle (game show)|Love Triangle]]'' (2011) for which she and her husband Kevin Hunter served as executive producers.<ref>[http://tv.gsn.com/shows/lovetriangle/ ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110122034045/http://tv.gsn.com/shows/lovetriangle/ |date=January 22, 2011 }}</ref>
Williams played a judge on the [[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime]] network show ''[[Drop Dead Diva]]'' (2011) and served as a guest judge on ''[[The Face (TV series)|The Face]]'' (2013).<ref name="Eur Web #2">{{cite web|url=http://www.eurweb.com/2013/02/wendy-williams-inks-first-look-deal-with-oxygen/|title=Wendy Williams Inks First Look Deal with Oxygen|last=Essex|first=Myeisha|date=February 5, 2013|work=EurWeb|accessdate=April 13, 2013}}</ref> She was also a contestant, paired with pro [[Tony Dovolani]] on [[Dancing with the Stars (U.S. season 12)|season 12]] of ''[[Dancing with the Stars (U.S. TV series)|Dancing with the Stars]]'' (2011); she was eliminated second.<ref>[http://abc.go.com/shows/dancing-with-the-stars/season-12-pros ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110304000601/http://abc.go.com/shows/dancing-with-the-stars/season-12-pros |date=March 4, 2011 }}</ref>
In February 2013, it was announced that Williams and her husband and manager, Kevin, were launching a reality television production company, Wendy Williams Productions.<ref name="Clutch Magazine">{{cite web |url=http://www.clutchmagonline.com/2013/02/wendy-williams-launches-reality-tv-production-company/ |title=Wendy Williams Launches Reality TV Production Company |work=Clutch Magazine |first=Myeisha |last=Essex |date=February 6, 2013 |accessdate=April 13, 2013}}</ref> that will produce unscripted content, including reality television and game shows.<ref name="Variety">{{cite news |url=https://variety.com/2013/tv/news/wendy-williams-launches-prod-n-shingle-1118065633/ |title=Talkshow maven pacts with manager and Debmar Mercury |work=Variety |first=AJ |last=Marechal |date=February 5, 2013 |accessdate=April 13, 2013}}</ref> Williams was an executive producer on the show ''[[Celebrities Undercover]]'' (2014).<ref name="Eur Web #2" />
Williams also executive produced the Lifetime [[biopic]] ''[[Aaliyah: The Princess of R&B]]'', which premiered on November 15, 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mylifetime.com/movies/aaliyah-the-princess-of-rnb |title=About |publisher=Aaliyah: The Princess of R&B |accessdate=April 14, 2015}}</ref> In September 2015, the documentary series ''[[Death By Gossip with Wendy Williams]]'' premiered on the [[Investigation Discovery]] channel, both hosted and produced by Williams.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2015/tv/news/id-series-barbara-walters-american-scandals-wendy-williams-death-by-gossip-1201553298/|title=Investigation Discovery Greenlights Series with Barbara Walters, Wendy Williams|first=Laura|last=Prudom|accessdate=August 31, 2015|date=August 19, 2015|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation]]}}</ref>
===Film=== Williams appeared in the [[film adaptation]] of [[Steve Harvey]]'s book, ''[[Act Like a Lady, Think Like a Man]]'', titled ''[[Think Like a Man]]'' (2012) and its sequel, ''[[Think Like a Man Too]]'' (2014).
In 2012, it was announced Williams would enter into a "production alliance" with producers [[Suzanne de Passe]] and [[Madison Jones]] to create movies and television shows aimed at multicultural audiences.<ref name="News One">{{cite web |url=http://newsone.com/2023239/wendy-williams-suzanne-de-passe/ |title=Wendy Williams, Suzanne DePasse Team Up on Multi-Picture Venture |work=Blast Zone Online |first=Ruth |last=Manuel-Logan |date=June 30, 2012 |accessdate=April 12, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Hollywood Reporter">{{cite news |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/wendy-williams-presents-movies-star-jones-343137 |title=Wendy Williams Aligns With de Passe Jones Entertainment for Scripted Ventures |work=The Hollywood Reporter |first=Alex |last=Bock |date=June 28, 2012 |accessdate=April 12, 2013}}</ref> These projects will appear under the heading "Wendy Williams presents"<ref name="Hollywood Reporter" /> and their first project will be VH1 adaptation of a [[Star Jones]] novel.<ref name="News One" />
===Theater=== In 2013, Williams announced she was going to play the role of Matron "Mama" Morton on the [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] musical ''[[Chicago (musical)|Chicago]]''.<ref>{{cite web |title=Wendy in Chicago on Broadway! |publisher=The Wendy Williams Show |url=http://www.wendyshow.com/wendy-in-chicago-on-broadway/ |accessdate=April 14, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title= Wendy Williams Will Join Cast of Broadway's Chicago This Summer |author=Andrew Gans |date=April 15, 2013 |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/wendy-williams-will-join-cast-of-broadways-chicago-this-summer-204409 |work=Playbill |accessdate=April 14, 2015}} </ref> Williams officially began her tenure on July 2<ref>{{cite web |title=Talk Show Queen Wendy Williams Brings Sass and Class to Her Big Broadway Bow in Chicago |author=Marc Snetiker |date=July 2, 2013 |url=http://www.broadway.com/buzz/170453/talk-show-queen-wendy-williams-brings-sass-and-class-to-her-big-broadway-bow-in-chicago/ |publisher=Broadway.com |accessdate=April 14, 2015}}</ref> and finished her 7-week run on August 11, 2013. Her preparations for the musical were documented in the TV Guide docuseries ''Wendy Williams: How You Doin', Broadway?!'',<ref>{{cite news |title=Wendy Williams Reality Series, John Rich Variety Show Coming to TV Guide Network |author=Jethro Nededog |date=July 17, 2013 |url=http://www.thewrap.com/tv/article/wendy-williams-reality-series-john-rich-variety-show-coming-tv-guide-network-103931/ |publisher=TheWrap |accessdate=April 14, 2015}}</ref> which was produced by her own production company, Wendy Williams Productions.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/07/17/wendy-williams-broadway-special-tvgn_n_3612016.html | publisher=The Huffington Post | first=Brennan | last=Williams | title=Wendy Lands Another Network Show | date=July 17, 2013}}</ref>
===Stand-up comedy=== Before Wendy turned 50, stand-up comedy was on her bucket list *In 2014, Lipshtick called Williams to participate in their first all-female-based comedy series at the Venetian in Las Vegas. *Williams made her sold-out comedy debut on July 11, 2014<ref>{{cite news |title=Wendy Williams Kicks Off 'Lipshtick – The Perfect Shade of Stand-Up' at The Venetian Las Vegas |date=July 14, 2014 |url=http://www.vegasnews.com/117845/wendy-williams-kicks-off-lipshtick-the-perfect-shade-of-stand-up-at-the-venetian-las-vegas.html |publisher=VegasNews.com |accessdate=April 14, 2015}}</ref> *Williams' comedy tour was called "The Sit-down Comedy Tour." *Williams returned to Lipshtick on October 31, 2014, and November 1, 2014, after she made a sold-out debut in July.<ref name="broadwayworld.com">{{cite news |title=Wendy Williams Returns to LA in LIPSHTICK – THE PERFECT SHADE OF STAND UP on 10/31011/1 |date=August 19, 2014 |publisher=BWW Comedy |url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/bwwcomedy/article/Wendy-Williams-Returns-to-LA-in-LIPSHTICK-THE-PERFECT-SHADE-OF-STAND-UP-on-10310111-20140819 |accessdate=April 14, 2015}}</ref> *Williams hosted her "How You Laughin'" Comedy Series at NJPAC on November 15, 2014 featuring Luenell, Jonathan Martin, Pat Brown, Hadiyah Robinson, and Meme Simpson.<ref>[http://www.njpac.org/events/detail/wendy-williams-presents-how-you-laughin] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141103010320/http://www.njpac.org/events/detail/wendy-williams-presents-how-you-laughin |date=November 3, 2014 }}</ref> *In 2015, Williams announced a 12-city comedy tour called "The Wendy Williams Sit Down Tour: Too Real For Stand-Up."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livenation.com/events/474918-aug-22-2015-the-wendy-williams-sit-down-tour-too-real-for-stand-up|title=The Wendy Williams "Sit Down Tour...Too Real For Stand Up|website=[[LiveNation.com]]|accessdate=April 10, 2017}}</ref>
==Business==
===HSN clothing line===
By partnering with the [[Home Shopping Network]] (HSN), Williams debuted a line of dresses, pants, sweaters and skirts fit for the everyday woman.The household name media mogul debuted her HSN Clothing line on March 28, 2015. The debut was a "sell-out success" and Williams even told viewers on her talk show that according to HSN, the debut was their most watched premiere since the onset of the program. The Wendy Williams line is sold exclusively at HSN.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://madamenoire.com/523076/wendy-williams-on-debuting-her-hsn-clothing-line/ |title=Wendy Williams On What Inspired Her HSN Clothing Line |website=MadameNoire.com |date=April 2, 2015 |accessdate=January 5, 2016}}</ref>
===Adorn===
Williams sells a line of jewelry products on the home shopping network, [[QVC]], called "Adorn by Wendy Williams".{{citation needed|date=February 2018}}
Williams and her husband, Kevin Hunter, commissioned the China-based manufacturing firm Max Harvest International Holdings to make 12,140 pairs of shoes bearing the logo of her brand, Adorn.<ref name="Eur Web #1">{{cite web |url=http://www.eurweb.com/2012/11/oh-gawd-wendy-williams-done-ran-out-on-a-419k-china-shoe-bill/ |title=Wendy Williams Runs Out on a $419K China Shoe Bill! |work=EurWeb |first= |last= |date=November 29, 2012 |accessdate=December 14, 2012}}</ref> The owners of Max Harvest International Holdings were said to have gone into hiding after the owner of the shoe factory who made the shoes kidnapped one of their managers and held the man prisoner for two weeks before releasing him, and Williams' failure to pay was cited the reason, reported by the New York ''Daily News''.<ref name="NY Daily News">{{cite news |url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2012-11-26/news/35370804_1_wendy-williams-shoes-hong-kong |title=Wendy Williams' failure to pay $400K reason for kidnapping |work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]] |first=Barbara |last=Ross |date=November 26, 2012 |accessdate=December 14, 2012 |location=New York}}</ref> The manager and his wife retained lawyer Staci Riordan of Los Angeles.<ref name="Business Insider">{{cite web |title=Wendy Williams' Massive Shoe Bill Allegedly Led to Kidnapping in China|url=http://au.businessinsider.com/wendy-williams-shoe-catastrophe-2012-11|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130628201555/http://au.businessinsider.com/wendy-williams-shoe-catastrophe-2012-11|dead-url=yes|archive-date=June 28, 2013|work=Business Insider |first=Abby |last=Rogers |date=November 28, 2012 |accessdate=February 11, 2013}}</ref> Their representative says they've been in negotiations for several months in order to reach a settlement.<ref name="Eur Web #1" /> Williams declined to comment on the matter.<ref name="Business Insider"/>
===Endorsements=== Williams was previously a spokesperson for Georges Veselle champagne.<ref>{{cite web|last=Stapleton |first=Susan |url=http://vegas.eater.com/2014/7/11/6188595/wendy-williams-talks-buffets-fans-and-nightlife-in-vegas |title=Wendy Williams Talks Buffets, Fans and Nightlife in Vegas – Eater Vegas |website=Vegas.eater.com |date= |accessdate=January 5, 2016}}</ref> She posed for [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals|PETA]]'s "I'd Rather Go Naked Than Wear Fur" advert campaign in 2012.<ref>"[http://www.nypost.com/p/pagesix/queen_strips_for_peta_gjoJbwlpClN4NZMSARjlLI%20 Media 'Queen' Wendy Williams Strips for PETA]," ''New York Post'', November 15, 2012.</ref>
==Personal life== In her biography, ''Wendy's Got the Heat'', she uses the [[pseudonym]] Robert Morris III to refer to her first husband and describes him as a salesperson.<ref name="Google Books">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=A_6UzticV84C&pg=PA105&lpg=PA105&dq=Wendy+Williams+husband+robert+morris&source=bl&ots=CRpcmpaVvB&sig=7WzrO-k-d4Ce71CHR8hxPGUcynk&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Gx_yUPT8COWq2QWuuIHADA&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Wendy%20Williams%20husband%20robert%20morris&f=false |title=Wendy's Got the Heat |first=Wendy |last=Williams |author2= Karen Hunter |publisher=Simon and Schuster |year=2004 |isbn=9780743470223 |page=105 |accessdate=January 12, 2013}}</ref> Williams and her first husband have since divorced.<ref name="NY Mag">{{cite web |url=http://nymag.com/nymetro/news/people/features/14790/index2.html |title=How New York's Shock Jockette Got Supersized |work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] |first= |last= |date= |accessdate=January 12, 2013}}</ref> On November 30, 1997, Williams married her second husband Kevin Hunter. Williams gave birth to their son, Kevin Hunter Jr., on August 18, 2000. Wendy is a [[Christian]] and has stated that she prays with her husband before every show.<ref>http://hollowverse.com/wendy-williams/</ref>
===Lawsuit=== In 2008, Nicole Spence, talent booker for ''The Wendy Williams Experience'', filed papers with the [[Equal Employment Opportunity Commission]] suing Williams. Spence claimed Williams' husband, Kevin Hunter, demanded sex from Spence on many occasions and created a hostile work environment by threatening and assaulting his wife on company premises.<ref name=FoxNews>[http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,341448,00.html "Court Papers: DJ Wendy Williams' Husband Beat Her, Propositioned Aide for Sex"], ''[[Fox News Channel]]'', March 25, 2008, Accessed July 22, 2008</ref><ref name="Parham">{{cite news |last=Parham|first=Marti|title=Wendy Williams: Unapologetic Radio Host Gets Her Shot At Network TV|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IDsDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA24&lpg=PA24&dq=wendy+williams+nicole+spence&source=bl&ots=CMHsjRfHJz&sig=-V8Vm1k2ZcdfP8oePAlI8aLaSdQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=S55PUeeDGNKy0QHRl4HoBQ&ved=0CNMFEOgBMGc#v|accessdate=March 25, 2013|newspaper=Jet|date=July 21, 2008}}</ref> On June 11, 2008, Spence filed a sexual-harassment lawsuit against Williams, Hunter, and [[Inner City Broadcasting Corporation]] in [[United States District Court for the Southern District of New York|federal court in Manhattan]].<ref>{{cite news |title=N.Y. radio host Wendy Williams sued for harassment|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/people/2008-06-11-wendy-williams_N.htm|accessdate=March 25, 2013|newspaper=USA Today|date=June 12, 2008}}</ref> Both Williams and Hunter deny the charges.<ref name="FoxNews"/><ref name="Buzz Briefs: Jay-Z, R. Kelly">[http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2008/06/12/entertainment/main4177283.shtml?source=related_story "Buzz Briefs: Jay-Z, R.
